terms.definition: The ability to obtain housing that fits a household’s needs, preferences, and financial capacity.
Ensuring all clients—regardless of background or circumstances—have fair opportunities to secure suitable housing.
Housing that minimizes entry requirements and conditions, increasing accessibility for people with complex needs.
A set of practical strategies focused on reducing negative consequences of high-risk behaviors, without requiring abstinence.
Adherence to core principles and standards of Permanent Supportive Housing to ensure quality and effectiveness.
A tool to view properties with lowered screening barriers and check availability to support client choice.
Landlord requirements used to qualify applicants, such as credit, criminal history, eviction history, debt, and income-to-rent ratios.
A threshold comparing tenant income to rent that may be negotiated to expand access.
Record of prior evictions that may trigger denials and should be discussed with landlords during negotiation.
Background information that may be used in screening; staff should advocate for reasonable, individualized consideration.
A numeric indicator of creditworthiness; strict cutoffs can be a barrier and may be negotiated.
Program supports offered to landlords—e.g., additional deposits or first and last month’s rent—to offset perceived risk.
The practice of honoring client preferences in selecting among viable housing options.
Staff support for viewing units, completing applications, and navigating next steps with the client.
Relationship-building and negotiation with property owners to reduce screening barriers and expand access.
